title: Head of anti-NHK party to run in Saitama upper house by-election
text:
The head of a minor opposition party critical of public broadcaster NHK says he is planning to run in an upper house by-election in Saitama Prefecture later this month.

Takashi Tachibana, known for his controversial remarks, most recently suggesting genocide is the solution to overpopulation, will give up his current Diet seat won in the July House of Councillors election through proportional representation if he runs for a constituency in the prefecture near Tokyo.

"It is true that I am arranging to quit (and newly file a candidacy)," Tachibana, 52, told reporters in the Diet building.

He posted video footage on the internet later, saying, "I will resign as a Diet member for a moment," adding he will hold a press conference later in the day.

Former Saitama Gov Kiyoshi Ueda, 71, has also said he will run in the Oct 27 by-election, for which official campaigning will begin Thursday.

Tachibana told a press conference last week that his party, the NHK Kara Kokumin Wo Mamoru To (the party to protect the people from NHK), will select a candidate for the by-election from among three party members.

Tachibana, a former employee of NHK, won his current Diet seat by calling for the abolition of the current mandatory payment of subscription fees to the public broadcaster.

After he quits, Satoshi Hamada, a doctor who earned the second-most votes in the party's list for proportional representation, will move up to fill his seat.

Tachibana was referred to prosecutors earlier this month on suspicion of threatening a local assemblyman in Tokyo in a YouTube video.
